title: 115_hr146
content: The Act is titled the "Eastern Band of Cherokee Historic Lands Reacquisition Act" and involves land being taken into trust for the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians. The Federal lands managed by the Tennessee Valley Authority in Monroe County, Tennessee, above the 820-foot contour elevation on Tellico Reservoir shores are declared to be held in trust by the United States for the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians. This includes approximately 46.0 acres known as the Sequoyah Museum property and approximately 11.9 acres known as the Support property. Approximately 18.2 acres of land, including Chota Memorial and Tanasi Memorial properties, are designated as part of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Historic Lands. The improvements on these lands, such as memorials, are the property of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians. The Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians own the memorials and properties on 18.2 acres of designated historic lands. The Tennessee Valley Authority must submit revised maps within a year of a land transaction, depicting the land taken into trust. Contour elevations are based on MSL Datum. The lands taken into trust are subject to conditions outlined in section 5. Permanent easements are taken into trust for the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians. Permanent easements below the 820-foot contour elevation on Federal lands in Monroe County, Tennessee, are held in trust by the United States for the benefit of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians. This includes approximately 8.5 acres for the Chota peninsula and 11.4 acres for the Chota-tanasi trail. The Tennessee Valley Authority will submit revised maps depicting lands subject to easements taken into trust under this section after consultation with the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians and the Secretary of the Interior. The lands subject to easements will be subject to use rights and conditions described in section 5. SEC. 4. TRUST ADMINISTRATION AND PURPOSES. The lands subject to this Act shall be administered under applicable laws and regulations for Indian tribes. The lands are to be used for memorializing Indian history and culture, recreational activities, and specific memorials and museums. The land described in section 2(a)(2) shall be used for supporting lands subject to the Act and programs offered by the Tribe, including classrooms, cultural education programs, temporary housing, and headquarters offices. The land described in section 3(a) is designated for recreational trails connecting the Chota and Tanasi Memorials with interpretive signs, benches, and other improvements. SEC. 5. USE RIGHTS, CONDITIONS. The Tennessee Valley Authority can flood lands and roads below the 824-foot contour elevation. The Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians can build water use facilities and nonhabitable structures between the 815-foot and 820-foot contour elevations with approval from the Tennessee Valley Authority. The Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians can construct water use facilities and have access to the Tellico Reservoir for transportation. They are allowed to use the lands subject to the Act for this purpose, but cannot interfere with river control and development. The Tennessee Valley Authority has the right to manage Tellico Reservoir, fluctuate water levels, and flood lands below a certain elevation as needed. They also have the right of entry to carry out their river control and development program. The Tennessee Valley Authority has the right to enter lands for river control and development activities, as long as it does not interfere with the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians' cultural preservation efforts. Future development on the lands will require compensation to the Authority for any loss of hydropower capacity. The Tennessee Valley Authority is not liable for any loss or damage resulting from flooding, wave action, or water level fluctuations in Tellico Reservoir. They also have sole responsibility for funding and implementing environmental remediation requirements. Prior to acquiring land into trust under this Act, an assessment must be conducted to identify any potential hazardous substances on the lands. The assessment should determine if hazardous substances were stored, released, or disposed of on the lands, and notify the relevant authorities accordingly. Before acquiring land into trust under this Act, an assessment must be conducted to identify any potential hazardous substances on the lands. If hazardous substances were found, the notice to the Secretary of the Interior and the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians should include the type, quantity, time of storage, release, or disposal, and any remedial actions taken. SEC. 6. LANDS SUBJECT TO THE ACT. The term "lands subject to this Act" refers to lands and interests taken into trust for the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians under this Act. SEC. 7. GAMING PROHIBITION. No class II or class III gaming allowed on these lands.
